text: {"grade": 0, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to explain that New York state courts enjoin international arbitration in limited circumstances, specifically when the arbitration agreement is null and void, inoperative, or incapable of being performed. The candidate answer focuses entirely on defending the *enforcement* of an award already rendered under the New York Convention (Article V defenses and pro-enforcement bias). It does not address the circumstances under which a New York court would *enjoin* (stop) the arbitration proceedings *before* an award is rendered, which is what the criterion asks about (i.e., the grounds for granting an anti-arbitration injunction in New York).", "criterion_id": "f24c358a-43a3-47ef-b32c-ce86625942a9"}
